title: i submit , the meta won
body: ive never touched an adc in all my time playing this game(disregarding featured game modes and arsm) never tried to actually learn the rople regularly and be good at it. ive always played assassins, roaming around killing everyone especially the adc so our team out dps in teamfights. now we get outlaned by mages who scale way better than us and have utility. not to mention we have the same burst window as combo mages now cuz "riot plz assassin oneshots 2 op". with ardent redemption locket jannas and lulu, ga and zhonyas, u have to try much harder and play much better than ur oppenents for a chance at winning as an assassin. guess its time to either learn adc and crit everyone to death in 3aas or become a better jg and hope i can keep them down the entire early and mid

replies.body: I'll take sentence structure for 2000

Jayce is still pretty good, his main weakness is getting shut down but once he makes it through he's staying in game. He scales pretty well late game considering his utility.

Lol, Im sorry but jayce doesn't really have utility, he has 1 cc which is a self peel, other than that he has poke and a lot of split push power.  Utility = playmaking power w/ CC to engage/disengage, or play stopping power, shields heals etc.

>u have to try much harder and play much better than ur oppenents for a chance at winning as an assassin

no you just have to not be horrible at the game, same skill level as your opponents suffices just fine.

Most assassins have a time limit of how long they are useful in the game so they have to actively create advantages instead of sitting and farming (try harder). The assassin player also has to outplay (play better) the opponent to start a snowball before they get outscaled at 20-25 minutes.
well either all assassin players are gods amongst men or you are wrong and assassin players are shit so that only leaves us with one option

No, there is a third option. Eventually people understand how assassins work and will actively help them start a snowball, from my experience this starts around high diamond. Junglers hand out ganks to you like candy if you pick an assassin, supports roam and ward for you, shoot sometimes even top laners show up occasionally.

Anywhere below that though I can be getting shoved in 24/7 with a pink in the river and my jungler will try to invade only to die and blame me. So in order to do well consistently below high diamond you have to be able to create your own leads and snowball just as I said above.

assassins generally have lane pressure and most mobility in the game at mid game, you should be playing around your jungler and other lanes not other way around. and with assassins maintaining a high win ratio at every elo you don't need to be a god to do well with them.

> assassins generally have lane pressure

Ha, depending on the match up you might have pressure at like level 3 but generally no you do not have lane pressure until level 6. At this point most mages can afk waveclear or in some cases they STILL beat you in a 1v1, you have to get a lead though or their cc or their supports 500 damage shields will outscale you in about 10-15 minutes.

> you should be playing around your jungler and other lanes

I'm not trying to say you're wrong, but winrates mean nothing if a 50%+ champion has a low playrate.

If a champion has ~300 games played with almost a 55% winrate, should we:

A) Take their position as stated for analytical purposes?

or

B) Try to guesstimate a 'better' winrate?

Personally I like to take established data over guesstimating, especially since the point is mages perform better with less work. A higher winrate with little playrate (and low average games played) means someone can pick up a champion and do exceptionally well with little to no work.

So sure normally you want an established winrate, but in context this data is absolutely fine.

I'm talking more about the winrates that accomplished mains and/or onetricks make. Someone like Aurelion Sol has a low playrate, but a high winrate. However, that's no reason to nerf him just because the mains are doing well.
